titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Wyandanch and Henry Whitnee land deed 1977.366
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-11-22 20:34:35 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Wyandanch and Henry Whitnee land deed
did.abstract: A photocopy of a deed documenting the sale of land by Wyandanch (often spelled Wyandance), Sachem (Chief) of the Montaukett (Montauk) Native Americans on Long Island, to Henry Whitnee of the town of Huntington.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection consists of a single document.

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals
originalsloc.p: The original deed was held in the Huntington Town Records at the time it was copied.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Wyandanch and Henry Whitnee land deed, 1977.366, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2023.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A photocopy of a deed documenting the sale of land by Wyandanch (often spelled Wyandance), Sachem (Chief) of the Montaukett (Montauk) Native Americans on Long Island, to Henry Whitnee of the town of Huntington. The deed is dated August 17, 1658.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
